text: zero DTE SPX spreads these are a strategy I've tested for a really long time and here are three super common mistakes when it comes to them and some ways we can overcome them what's up everybody Eric here welcome back to all the outliers and we were talking about a super common strategy today a lot of people I know like to trade the strategy myself included but there are some really really common errors people make so first let's get a quick Baseline on what this strategy is the zero DTE SPX strategies there's a ton of different forms and Fashions of them sometimes people will trade short strangles sometimes they will trade short straddles sometimes short iron Condors that are far out of the money so on and so forth there's a lot of variations and I'm not going into all of them today what I do want to talk about today are some of the more common variations and the issues with them so one of the most common variations I've seen is essentially a short wide far out of the money iron Condor so what that looks like is if I come over to the trade tab I typically would see a zero DTE obviously it's the weekend right well now obviously you would know that I know that today is the 23rd of October it's Sunday so there's no zero DTE right now but normally there would be so let's just pretend that this

text: trade tab I typically would see a zero DTE obviously it's the weekend right well now obviously you would know that I know that today is the 23rd of October it's Sunday so there's no zero DTE right now but normally there would be so let's just pretend that this one DTE is actually zero DTE we would pop this open and then a lot of people go super far out of the money for the short option so let's start with the put side and let's say we go to this 10 Delta far out of the money short put and then you would buy and even further out of the money um long put essentially to create a hedge now there's a couple big issues with this the first one is the use of spreads in my opinion is an inefficient way to trade this strategy what is this strategy anyways why do we trade it in short what we're attempting to do is harvest the volatility risk premium and what that means is if I zoom in on a slightly shorter time period and we look down at this weird looking series of lines I am charting out implied volatility versus historic volatility that is the entire purpose of the zero DTE strategies is we are attempting to trade the typical overstatement of implied volatility to Historic volatility the problem is we are making the assumption that implied volatility is high relative to Historic volatility that is

text: out implied volatility versus historic volatility that is the entire purpose of the zero DTE strategies is we are attempting to trade the typical overstatement of implied volatility to Historic volatility the problem is we are making the assumption that implied volatility is high relative to Historic volatility that is why we sell premium in these strategies the big problem problem is if you're trading a spread okay we're selling the volatility in this 10 Delta short put but then we're buying the very same volatility that we think is overpriced that's the first problem people are uncomfortable taking risk so they seek to hedge out this risk using spreads like this and that is an issue because you are literally contradicting the entire trade hypothesis that you're starting with now to be abundantly clear that is not to suggest that all spreads like this vertical spreads or Condors are immediately contradictory in nature for some people they will use that far out of the money Wing just as a way to hedge Black Swan risk no problem if we want to do that let's use some data to inform our decision cycle and what I mean by that is maybe we only do it on the put side because markets tend to move down much lower far more aggressively than they do to the upside so if that's our concern instead of just automatically doing some sort of condor maybe we only do it on the put side where

text: maybe we only do it on the put side because markets tend to move down much lower far more aggressively than they do to the upside so if that's our concern instead of just automatically doing some sort of condor maybe we only do it on the put side where the risk typically lays but for me more frequently than not I would prefer just to use short straddles or short strangles typically a short straddle is better off in my opinion next one non-discerning entry this is the most important one out of this list I put it number two in case you want to jump ship early which you shouldn't you should stay to the end because the last one's actually really interesting in conjunction with the first one but let's talk about the second one non-discerning entry if I look at these different lines you'll notice I have a bright yellow a dark yellow and then a white the white line is implied volatility and then the historic volatility that's more pertinent to this conversation is this brighter yellow which is the 30 day now you you'll notice there are periods of time where the actual historic volatility is greater than the implied volatility so if we simply just every single day trade this strategy you are indiscerningly of throwing out something that's supposed to capitalize on a specific environment and some of those environments it doesn't so we need to pay close attention to the relationship

text: volatility is greater than the implied volatility so if we simply just every single day trade this strategy you are indiscerningly of throwing out something that's supposed to capitalize on a specific environment and some of those environments it doesn't so we need to pay close attention to the relationship between implied volatility and historic volatility again based on the time frames that you're trading but this entire strategy is predicated on implied volatility typically being slightly overstated compared to Historic volatility so if you just randomly wheel this strategy all the time because it's the only thing you know you are using the strategy in periods of time where it actually doesn't make sense so you've got to pay attention to that okay the last one is some people do this really interesting thing where we kind of combine both of these entities meaning we use spreads to spread off our risk but then we also put stops on those spreads the problem with this is as soon as you start integrating stops into this kind of strategy the numbers change significantly and I know what you're saying Eric I've seen it back tested it looks great the problem with back tests on strategies like this is they miss things like slippage they're not super specific to the strategy as it is and again unless we get very very pointed with our back testing to include periods where implied volatility actually is overstated compared to when it's not using

text: with back tests on strategies like this is they miss things like slippage they're not super specific to the strategy as it is and again unless we get very very pointed with our back testing to include periods where implied volatility actually is overstated compared to when it's not using stops on these spreads essentially kneecaps the strategy you are trying to capture a variance in volatility but then you're not giving the trade the space it needs to move and I've actually done videos dissecting this more in detail but the fact of the matter is stops on spreads again not saying it's always the wrong answer but you got to look really carefully at what's happening to the expectancy of the strategy what ends up happening with this kind of setup more often than not especially if it's coupled with all three of these in conjunction with one another is we run into a scenario where we are taking a lot of very small profits and we're taking fewer big losses but those losses tend to overwhelm the majority of those frequent small profits so it's not as simple as set this strategy up because you saw it somewhere Run and Gun and you'll make a bunch of money there's more to it than that and if you've been trading for any period of time you probably guessed that because far more frequently than not things tend to be a little deeper as you peel back especially this
